interesting election coverage this year...an incumbent terror-warrior versus two of the richest men to seek the high office in American history. It's like Field of Dreams for real..."if you build the campaign, they will come." the conventions are rock concerts for old people. The lollapalooza for all the hall monitors and squealers of the world. is there anything more unconventional than a convention? If you're a politico, your job is to convince enough people you deserve the gig to have it? What if all gigs were like that? With most jobs you're trying to convince two, maybe three people tops, that you deserve it. What if to get a gig at Fed Ex you had to bring in a petition of three thousand signatures? Would you be able to do it?

My connect at Citadel systems was this tall, thin Japanese guy named Chen. He told us to meet him at the News Bar in the Village. He was a tech assistant in the video game R D department. Heâd been there since his teenage years and was considered to be the Mozart of software programming. But over the last year the shine on his star has begun to fade and he was demoted to a lowly ops assistant despite the company posting a modest 30 million dollar profit for two quarters in a row. After he was dissed for a promotion for the third time, I heard about him unloading prototypes at cost. I hooked him up with this big-breasted com specialist from NASA named Doris and heâs treated me like his best friend ever since. Chen hits me off with beta tested prototypes just to see how well they work. Then I sell copies to a few knock off companies I know. Pirate video games are still big on the black market. I told Gypsy, my intrepid tour guide, âNow, when we get in here, donât say anything to him, only me. Heâs crazy paranoid because the Citadel has people watching him. When I talked to him on the phone, he sounded like he was wigged out on Ping and up all night flying in from Paris.â âUsually no, but in his condition now, I say all bets are off. The only thing know I he isnât armed.â âIâll tell you what,â Gypsy said as we entered the News Bar. We sat at a table near the window facing the street so Chen would see us. âYou buy one of those bottled juices over there and drink it down fast, then give it to me. If he tries anything, Iâll bust his ass with that bottle, but good.â âJust be cool man-" I said, stopping when I saw Chen at the window peering in. He was carrying a thick Halliburton briefcase. I motioned to Gypsy to go get a juice from the bar as entered and sat down. âWhat took you so long, man? Iâve been waiting almost an hour. I had to go get coffee-â âGet coffee?â I said, âChen, this is a coffee bar-â âCoffee sucks in here. I had to Dean and Deluca down the street". âJust relax, Chen,â I said. He was more jittery than I thought. Chen was built like an Olympic swimmer, and his clothes always hung off of him. He was in a wrinkled black Italian suit, a white button down with a stain on the front, Frankenstein shoes, bug-eye wraparound shades and a red fez. âThis wonât take long, Iâll get you back to the airport myself.â I flipped open my phone and dialed Jojo the Limo Driver. âWhat do you have for me?â Finally he seemed to relax and began to laugh. âI made this especially for you.â He put his case on the table and opened it. Gypsy came over with a nearly empty Snapple bottle. Chen tensed back up. âWho's he?â âHeâs my ride,â I said, looking in the case, âThis looks like a video camera.â âIt is, except is uses a hard disk recording mechanism and the lens is especially designed for shooting bright targets in low light. Itâs my movie bootlegger special.â âSo I can take this to a movie theatre and shoot a better copy of the movie?â âBetter than in the ones youâve been sending me. But listen, you need a Teledyne Video Imager to filter the picture before you put it on videotape or DVD. Without it, you have copies that look like copies." Chen said. âAnd you did this for me? Thatâs touching. This thing is impressive. You still have any contacts in Southeast Asia? I can get Tom Cruiseâs new movie next week, and I want to turn it over fast.â Chen started staring intently at his hands and rocking in his seat. âIâll have to call you about that. Look, wire-transfer money six thousand for camera. And a few valium; I need some sleep.â Me and Gypsy looked disgustedly at each other. âGoddammit Chen, why didnât you say that on the phone. I asked you if you were cool and you said yes!â âLook Myron X, Iâm sorry, you know Iâm not usually like this, but the pressure is killing me! The only time we are not watched is when weâre at work, So the only place any of us feels safe is at work. All the techs in my sector are either on powerful psychoactive drugs or banging each other in lice-ridden opium dens in Shanghai harbor. The perversion of people under stress is astounding. You know I havenât slept in four days?â I looked at Gypsy. He whispered to me he had maybe a half dozen Adovans and eight pellets of Ya Ba, a wicked, savage recreational drug from Thailand. If I gave Chen any of that crap, heâd be a serial killer by tomorrow afternoon. The drugs would have to wait. My phone rang. I handed it to Gypsy. âIf thatâs Jojo, tell him I have any emergency rush to Kennedy for double the fee. Ask him if heâs get any Vees.â âTake care of that camera." Chen said. "I may be traded soon.â âTraded? Like a baseball player?â âKind of.â A rival company will post a job opening at my level, maybe for a little more money, a little more prestige. Who ever the job listing is posted for always finds that person somehow. Then my company will do the same thing. Iâll apply over there and get hired and the same will happen at my company.â âWhat if you stay on?â âThen the job goes to someone else and you get phased.â âPhased?â âYeah, phased out of your section, then youâre department, then out of the building.â âJesus, thatâs harsh. You should defect. Can you do that?â âDo you know what kind of voodoo Iâd have to pull off to get that kind of action? Only the superstars even get that option. Everybody else is straight hustling. Iâm telling you man, the more money this tech shit makes, the more these assholes want to play hardball.â Chen lit his third Pall Mall and stared past my shoulder at the street. I felt bad; all he probably needed was a couple hours in the Geisha House Massage Parlor, and Iâd love to take care of him, but there was no time. Gypsy tapped his watch to remind me we still had a meeting with Dr. Hanif âHorseshoeâ Muradi, noted electronic systems theorist and compulsive gambler. We sat quietly until JoJo the Limo Driver screeched to a halt outside in his fire engine red Cadillac stretch. We went outside. JoJo got out of the car. Sorry Iâm late man, I had to run to the Bronx. Where we going?â âTo the airport. Kennedy. This is my man Chen. Heâs very cool people, so donât mess with him, and donât give him the run around. Unload him at Kennedy at the British Airways terminal. Can I give you the fee later?â âYeah, no big deal. But cash though. You got an Valiums?â Iâm still speeding from two days ago.â Jesus, doesnât anybody just go to bed anymore? âAll I got left are some Adovans." I looked in my kit bag. I found a 35mm film canister half full of tiny yellow pills. I took out ten, took another two and swallowed them, then pulled Chen around to the other side of the car. I handed him the vial. âDonât give JoJo any until you are out of the car at the airport. That flaky bastard will take them while heâs driving and youâll end up in Boston.â I put Chen in the car and looked at Gypsy. He lit a Camel and spat at a dog pissing in the gutter. The limo pulled off down Sixth Avenue. We grabbed the camera and split.

I'm approaching the two thirds mark of my novel "Word is Bond". This is the part of the marathon where you being to hallucinate and wonder why you thought this was so important to begin with. As long as I stay consistent with the theme, then I can make it to the other side. The whole point is Silver is a bad person that wants to be a good person. She lies, cheats and steals, but only so she can provide for her friend Marris and her daughter India, the closest thing she has to a family. It isn't that she doesn't believe in love, she just doesn't think she deserves it. So far everyone that's read it, got into it, although my first lesson is don't let anyone read it until it's finished, or close to it. And, until you write the words "THE END" you got nothing. I shoulda been an architect or a dentist...

LADY DAY by Myron X. I liked to drink with Lady Day because she was an ex-hippie jazz head from way back. Now she was the 48 year old owner of the Harbor Bar and grill in the small Jersey shore town of Long Branch. Whenever I needed to get out of New York and have a look around, I frequently found myself at her place. It was a block from the train station and I was always welcome on her couch. She told colorful stories of her exploits and tactics during the social revolution of the 60s. She claimed to be one of the few that attended Woodstock and Altmont and survived them both. I sat at the bed of the dark bar closest to the door and sipped a glass of wine while she herded the last of her regular customers out the door and locked it behind them. âMy regulars think Iâm having an affair with you.â She sat on the stool next to mine and poured her herself the remains of the carafe she set out for me. She was a weary white woman that filled a pair of jeans to the limit with her meaty hips, not wide, but soft and fleshy. Her eyes were a liquid light blue and she always kept a pack of cowboy killers in the breast packet of her ex-husbandâs short sleeved, white Arrow shirts, which she was always wearing. Her D-cup support bra always showed through the material of the shirt. âWho cares about them? Theyâre just mad because youâve developed a taste for chocolate.â She let out a low, sexy gut laugh that never quite made it past her lips. âI care about them sweetie. They make up with their wives and Iâm out of business. Iâve always had a sweet tooth though.â âYou just after me for my money.â âWhat money?â âThe fortunes Iâm going to be swimming in after I sell this movie Iâm writing. Iâm buying an island in the Caribbean. Wanna come for a swim?â âYouâre cute. You remind me of this guy I used to date named Kevin. He was black. He was the sexiest man-he looked like Jim Brown.â âWho?â âYou mean to tell me-â âIâm just kidding.â âWe used to lay on the floor of his filthy apartment in Newark naked and high on pot listening to Miles Davis reading Eldridge Cleaver or Malcom X-he used to call me his funny valentine. You donât remember that, do you?â âOf course I do.â I said. I hummed a few bars of it into the bottom of my glass. She poured another one for each of us. She took a cigarette out of her pack and I lit it for her. âI got a wedding invitation from my step-daughter the other day. Remember I told you about the guy Stephanie moved to Maine with, the dentist? Well, she got a ring out of him, along with the house with the white picket fence and the family car in the driveway.â âYou sound like itâs pissing you off.â âIt is...and it isnât. Lord knows Iâm glad Stephi stopped being a silly-assed tart and settled herself down, and I hope it lasts, I really hope it does. I hope sheâs got some substance to her, not all shallow like her father. Boy, he was a piece of work. Worked like a slave just so he could have the latest whatever-car, tape deck, tennis racket, motorcycle, you name it. Thatâs how he always measured his success in real estate-by how much he had. At first he loved me because I was so simple; earthy was his term. Fifteen years later it was the very thing he couldnât deal with. I didnât want any of his junk, I wasnât impressed with it. Said I was so behind the times. The smartest two things I did in my life was let him buy this place for me and letting him skip off to California with his vapid little secretary Tina Big Tits." âTina Big Tits...she sounds like a blow-up doll.â âShe was. And she did anything he said. He needed a woman like that, some gum-chewing, salad-eating bubble-head to do his bidding and his laundry. He used to like me because I sassed him. Then that changed and he had to get some from somewhere else. âIt didnât bother you he was cheating on you?â âOf course it did. He was my husband after all. I did love him in some twisted way. He was a liar and a cheap hustler, but he didn't start that way. Thatâs why I didnât give him a hassel about a divorce. I told him to do what he wanted as long as he signed the bar over to me. He couldnât handle his liquor anyway.â I nodded as she stubbed out her cigarette and gulped down the last of her wine. Lady Day was a cool jazz melody that simply didnât end, she just hung in the air like cigarette smoke.
